metadata.case_name: Purshottam Trikamdas & Ors. v. State of Bombay

facts.text: Appellants hold personal inams covered by Bombay Acts Nos. II and VII of 1863.

Bombay Act No. II of 1863 applied to certain parts of Presidency of Bombay, allowing holders of lands wholly or partially exempt from land-revenue to consent to terms for perpetual continuance of lands upon payment of fixed annual nazrana (one anna per rupee of assessment) and quit-rent equal to one-fourth of assessment, thus paying five annas in the rupee of full assessment.
Bombay Act No. VII of 1863 applied to remaining parts, with quit-rent of two annas per rupee of assessment, thus paying two annas in the rupee.
Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, No. XLII of 1953 (the Act) challenged as unconstitutional.
Writ petitions filed in Bombay High Court as Special Civil Applications Nos. 393, 395, 409, 632, 1205, 1309 of 1954, dismissed on July 6, 19, 30 1954.
Certificate granted by Bombay High Court for appeals to Supreme Court.
Section 2(c) of the Act defines 'inamdar' as holder of personal inam and includes persons holding under him.
Section 2(d) defines inam village or inam land; Section 2(e) defines personal inam.
Section 3 excludes certain inams including devasthan inams or those held by religious/charitable institutions as per Explanation.
Section 4 extinguishes all personal inams and rights therein (with immaterial exceptions).

Section 5 makes inam villages/lands liable to full land-revenue under Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879; inamdar becomes occupant liable for full revenue (exception for inferior holders paying full assessment to inamdar).
Section 7 vests certain lands (roads, paths, water bodies, waste lands etc.) in State Government.
Sections 8-9 deal with trees and mines.
Section 10 provides compensation for extinguishment under Section 7; Section 11 appeal therefrom.
Section 17 provides compensation for extinction/modification not covered by Section 10, but subsection (5) excludes compensation for making inam lands subject to full assessment.
Sections 12-16 procedural; Section 17A bonds; Section 18 applies Bombay Tenancy Act; Section 19 rules; Section 20 repeals.

legal_issues.text: Whether the property dealt with under the Act is not an estate within Article 31A.
Whether no compensation has been provided in the Act for taking away the property of the appellants.

petitioner_arguments.text: The property dealt with under the Act is not an estate.
What Sections 4 and 5 extinguish is the right to appropriate the difference between full assessment and quit-rent, which is not a right in an estate.
The Act does not provide for compensation and is ultra vires Article 31.

respondent_arguments.text: The Act is protected under Article 31A of the Constitution.

court_reasoning.text: Inams are specifically included in the definition of 'estate' under Article 31A(2)(a); the Act deals with inams and is protected from attacks under Articles 14, 19, 31.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Estate' includes any jagir, inam or muafi.

court_reasoning.text: Right to retain part of full assessment over quit-rent arises from holding the inam-estate and is a right in an estate; also included in 'rights or privileges in respect of land revenue' under Article 31A(2)(b); falls under Section 3(5) of Bombay Land Revenue Code.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rights in relation to an estate include rights vesting in intermediaries and privileges in respect of land revenue.

court_reasoning.text: Act provides compensation under Section 10 for lands vested under Section 7, and Section 17 for other cases (except loss from full assessment per subsection 5); Article 31A saves from attack under Article 31.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Article 31A protects from compensation requirement under Article 31.

holdings.text: Inams are estates under Article 31A; rights extinguished/modified are rights in an estate; Act protected by Article 31A from challenges under Articles 14, 19, 31.
Absence of compensation for loss from paying full assessment does not invalidate Act due to protection under Article 31A.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, No. XLII of 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolishes personal inams, vests certain lands in State, imposes full land-revenue, provides limited compensation; upheld as constitutional under Article 31A.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act No. II of 1863
statutes_cited.relevance: Granted perpetual rights to inamdars on payment of partial assessment (quit-rent one-fourth plus nazrana).

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act No. VII of 1863
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar to Act II but quit-rent two annas per rupee.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies full land-revenue to inam lands post-abolition; rights under it; records for exclusions.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948
Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Article 31A protects Act from challenges under 14,19,31; defines estate and rights therein.

outcome.summary: The appeals challenging constitutionality of Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1953 on grounds that inams are not estates and no compensation provided, are dismissed as the Act is protected by Article 31A.

key_quotes.text: 'Estate' shall... include any jagir, inam or muafi or other similar grant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly includes inams within Article 31A protection.

key_quotes.text: The rights in relation to an estate would include any rights or privileges in respect of land revenue.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Covers inamdar's right to retain difference between full assessment and quit-rent.

key_quotes.text: There is no force in these appeals and they are hereby dismissed with costs.
key_quotes.speaker: court
